body:
I have committed this to the master branch. This’ll show up in a CouchDB release near you soon :)

Could you close this PR for us (we currently can't, thanks!)

I am just a user of jquery.couch.js who found something that was broken not really someone hacking on the couchdb source. I looked at auth_cache.js, but it's not clear to me how to run the tests or make my own. I use https://github.com/iriscouch/build-couchdb to get my couchdb running. If you let me know how to run the test suite I can see if I can figure out how to add a test for this.

1. Start CouchDB
2. Open http://127.0.0.1:5984/_utils
3. Go to "Test Suite"
4. Either run All Tests, or individual tests by clicking the arrow next to them

You can find the source for the test cases in `share/www/script/test/`.

Thanks for your help! Let us know if you have any more questions! :)
Woot!

Awesome work guys! Really increases the number of ways you can use couch
without wrapping a web tier around it...

On Thu, Nov 15, 2012 at 3:01 PM, Caleb Case notifications@github.comwrote:

> Woot!
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/apache/couchdb/pull/18#issuecomment-10425219.

@janl: we're moving towards a custom API, so our browser components won't communicate directly with CouchDB through `$.couch`. Sadly @boxxxie and I weren't allowed more time to clean up the rest of the code and create proper patches. Unless we "find time", there probably will not be any more changes from us. Sorry about that :(
@joelpurra thanks for the update. I think it’d be safe to close the PR then, right? Could you do that for us (we currently can’t, thanks! :)

I'm going to close the PR, however i still use this library for other projects and I will most likely find time to work on it more in the future. I'll do a proper branch and PR next time (sometime soon).
Great, thank you! :)
applied.

Thanks @JakubOboza however `bootstrap` is only needed for building from git checkouts. We cover that info in `DEVELOPERS` https://github.com/apache/couchdb/blob/master/DEVELOPERS#L103.

How do you think we can make this more accessible/easy to follow?

Oh so i wanted to hack a bit in the sources and i did stupid thing i cloned the source and started to follow build instructions to be sure i can build it before diving in :D. I missed the developer text.
You guys could also add --prefix= into develoeprs docs to point out how to build it into location. I know every developer knows this but its good as a hint :)
Applied, thanks! :)
We could link to contributing.md in the .rst docs.

I guess the other thing to note, is that CONTRIBUTING.md is maintained in markdown, which will be inconsistent with the rst (wiki?) syntax (I've not familiarized to the rst stuff yet, myself). Not sure if this is concerning to anyone, but deserves to be considered.
@emjayess if we just maintain this file and link to it in the rat docu, we don’t duplicate efforts or run into cross-markup issues.

@janl nod - however I also only just now noticed that github does quite a fine job of rendering the ReStructured Text, so perhaps that could be used instead of traditional github markdown? 

Not sure if it requires the .rst extension as a tip-off, and if so, not sure if it would automatically hoist a `contributing.rst` as the formal policy file. hrrrmmmm.

UPDATE: so i just tried it on another project and github indeed DOES recognize `contributing.rst` as a bonafide policy file as per above...

so next question: can you move the contributing.rst file from the docs dir to the root, and symlink it back into the docs dir? I probably didn't need to do any of this markdown file fluff. 

Do you even want to mix a project-wide contributing policy with one for contributing to docs in the first place?

Sorry for all the questions. #NowWeKnow

no worries, this discussion itself is helpful.

I don’t know if a symlink will do, but having a 
./CONTRIBUTING.rst -> share/doc/src/contributing.rst would be desireable, if the docs build system can cope with it
Lots of repos is confusing. Closing this as the expected "fauxton" branch is missing commits from when this branched. Will do a more sane PR later.

-1 on merging, this patch is not ready.
-    io:format("info ~p ~n",[[Start, Bytes]]),

use of foldr, etc.
We prefer binaries to lists, is there a fix for this that goes the other way?

@rnewson That's not true. When headers are used with CORS they always only work with lists, not binaries.

Of course the code base could be changed so that all headers use binaries and CORS always converts the binaries to lists. But that's not the point of this patch :)
I understand the point of the patch, I'm just saying that if we are trying to fix this mismatch we prefer binaries over lists. If that's a much uglier patch (or even impossible) fair enough.

Now I got the point. I fear to break something with changing the headers from lists to binaries. From the source it looked like lists were preferred. So I would go with this patch and make it properly once we the whole HTTP layer gets cleanup/rewritten.
sounds good.
merged, thanks! please to close pull, yah?
Thanks for merging so quickly.

This can be closed/rejected in favor of a CONTRIBUTING.rst file in root - although the outstanding thing that I'm not sure how to resolve yet is how best to keep a `/contributing.rst` and `/share/doc/src/contributing.rst` in sync. 

As a refresher, the whole basis for keeping a copy in the project root is that github picks it up and alerts newcomers to the policy for contributing (it's be sweet if @github just allowed a file path to be specified in e.g. project admin).
@nslater-asf did u remark to the effect of potentially changing the format from .rst to something else? I got an email, but not sure what happened to the comment...

Add `erlang-eunit, erlang-xmerl, perl-core` to that list for tests.

And `make && make check` works even though make distcheck doesn't.

`rev_stemming` fails sometimes during automated run, works fine on its own.

@dch I've been getting random failures like this as well. Both Fedora and Centos. If you manually re-run, it may pass.
Woha, excellent Pull Request! <3

Wow, best PR ever. Many thanks @argl!

+1 on a quick inspection.

Thanks for the encouragement. I am really moved since its my first pull request ever and Erlang is really not my primary language (wipes tear off cheek). I'll try my best to completely solve the rest of couchdb-259.
This should also get backported to the 1.3.x branch.

Applied to 1.0.x & master.

Thanks for the heads up!

This looks good. I ran into https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COUCHDB-1711 while testing this, so I can’t vouch for this just yet, but once 1711 is out of the way and this still passes, I am happy to get this merged. Sorry for the delay!
Thanks Jan

Sorry if this is the wrong place to ask, but is there an active maintainer of the Geocouch Readme.md? After building couchbase 2.0 from src, the test instructions seems out of date wrt 2.0 install paths, and the REST URI end-points don't work as described (have to use web ui to create buckets, add view doc).
Merged, thanks!
mm that Travis build shows some JS errors.. I used the 1.3.0 tag to base my changes, and only have two in an erl file.

@janl, @dch, this is still an issue.

Use case: My app uses longpolls on different filtered changesets. I open new connections, but the old ones remain active. After 6 are opened, the browser refuses to make any other connections to the server, since it has reached the maximum number of parallel connections. The app becomes completely unresponsive. I don't need the old longpolls any more, since they are for pages we have moved away from, so I would like to be able to cancel them.

I'm planning on using @indutny's patch, but it would be nice for future users to have it in the mainline.
Thanks!

@stefankoegl vielen dank! To keep CI happy we need to be able to run `make distcheck` successfully. I _could_ tell you what changes are needed to the PR, but if you want to have a go, please do so. If you just want the answers, then look at some of the docs commits in 1.3.x branch from me.  @kxepal is going to include this in the next 1.3.x release along with some other changes, so stand by.
@JakubOboza are you able to close this PR? we've already got it committed but can't close from our end. Thanks!
@JakubOboza are you able to close this PR, I don't think we need it now!
@wendall911 can you close this PR? thanks!
Sure thing, I thought I had already for some reason!

I've updated the the commit by adding the new replicator page to share/doc/build/Makefile.am, but the build is still failing. When looking at [one of the failed builds](https://travis-ci.org/apache/couchdb/jobs/6865595), I see

```
make[2]: Leaving directory `/home/travis/build/apache/couchdb/apache-couchdb-1.4.0+build.c8db7bc/_build'
Running javascript tests ...

Done. Your build exited with 1.
```

which does not even look docs-related. Any pointers?
@stefankoegl \o/ your patch LGTM, let's go with that -- thanks! I'll take a look on Monday at the other error, it's clearly unrelated.
Moved this to a JIRA ticket https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COUCHDB-1786
@dileepbapat looks good to me for a first glance, let's wait for a couple of the upstream packagers to comment before committing it. Many thanks for the patch!
created https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COUCHDB-1795
Thanks @deathbearbrown I've meged this into master. Could you close this pull request as I cant.

I think 5s is too low. We can be much smarter about this whole thing, IMO.

What do you think of
- Backoff 2x as before
- Limit the backoff only to cases where the connection timed out. Losing connectivity should mean total, fast failure in many cases, and we could detect the difference between these cases. In the case of server error or no connectivity, that error should bubble immediately and the application can decide what to do (either sleep, back off, or hook into the connectivity notification APIs that are cropping up in modern browsers)
- Add a random jitter to the back-off. When timeouts are happening because the server is overwhelmed it could help to prevent clients from stampeding. Such a jitter is a classic feature of backoffs like this.

Finally, I haven't looked at this code in a while, but we should be sure that the whole thing is cancellable by the application in case the backoff gets large.

Agreed. Rather selfishly, for my own uses I just want it to keep trying rather than back off at all. So this is more of a "are you aware of this issue" rather than an actual proposed fix. 

I'm not sure who is looking after this plugin - but I'm happy to code these additions if it would be appreciated, otherwise the current maintainer might want to look at the issue.
The whole community maintains it, so feel free to submit another changeset!
@vmx can you close this out?
That got fixed.
What's the status of this PR?
What's the status of this PR?
What's the status of this PR?
like @davisp said the performance qould be terrible until at least we improve all the engine imo.

My understanding was that no one wanted this as done here, though the use case comes up on the mailing list regularly. The primary point is that it's not possible to have nice URLs, sufficiently unique IDs, and REST at the same time without more powerful rewriting than what we currently have.

@darobin I'd suggest you bring this up in a DISCUSS thread on dev@, and let's see if we can form some consensus around the best way forward. That sort of discussion is not best done in a pull request.

In the meantime, can we close out this PR?

It took me a few minutes to figure out what's going on here.  The issue is that when the rewriter sets a `#user_ctx` on the request it bypasses all of the auth handlers on the second time around.  That's a good thing, but it means that `#httpd.auth` is undefined, which means that when we call `couch_httpd_auth:cookie_auth_header/2` it won't add a new `Set-Cookie`.

The code looks good.  Thanks for the contribution!

@unclespode Cool. Thanks for the pull request. I'd love to see the fuller solution (distinguish timeouts from fast, total connection failure), but it's not critical. If you get the time to improve this please put it here. As is, though, I'm ambivalent about what is the better default.

I've been working on the code as I develop my project at the moment. I've actually written EventSource (SSE) support into the changes function, so that it prefers this over longpolling, with a fallback to long polling where it isn't available, with no discernible difference as far as the coder is concerned.

I won't submit the patch until it's finalised.

Hi @stefankoegl !
Sorry for delay, just [committed](https://git-wip-us.apache.org/repos/asf?p=couchdb.git;a=commit;h=eb364ff) your changes with @P-Product fix.  Could you close this pull request?
Thanks :)
After talking to Russell/Garren we are going to do this differently

Hey @deathbearbrown 

I've been trying this out on, I really like what you have done here but we need to extend this a little further. Currently the loader only gets displayed after the Route Object has finished its establish(). Which means that there is still a lengthy period when the screen is just blank. I think we need to add `disableLoader` and `loaderClassname` to the RouteObject and then just after Line 256, in that `if` statement, add `$('#dashboard').addClass(routeObject.loaderClassname)`.
I did a quick hack of that and it makes it quite a bit better as it then has a loader on the screen straight away. Obviously that loader has to be removed before we start displaying the view loaders. Would also like to know what 
@chewbranca thinks of this.
Hey, I added an update to include the extra loader.  I changed it to add to $('#app-container') for reasons I mentioned in the jira ticket.
thanks @deathbearbrown this is great. I've squashed and merged it into master. You will have to close this pull request.
Thank you! :sparkles:
Any news?
Fixed properly by [this pull request](https://github.com/apache/couchdb/pull/66)
merged to master and 1.3.x independently.
Before you'll say anything, I want to mention that this is very important for npm and it's private clones.
And /cc @isaacs

Yes, please!  +1

I'm effectively doing this manually with the npm registry via a rather convoluted replication process.
/cc @jhs
I like the intention here but I'd like to see the whitelist externalized.

Putting the blacklist of fields in a config would be good.  I know that some couch apps would probably like to hide email, as well.

Making it a whitelist-only would be less ideal for me, but not completely terrible.
sorry, blacklist is fine, but from config.
A thought, name the config setting "user_field_exclude" (or similar) and we could add "user_field_include" in a future patch for more flexibility akin to rsync's --include and --exclude filters.

mmm shouldn't it whitelisting for consistancy with other part of the conf? We are using whitelisting for "config_whitelisting" and same for "http_globlals".

As for the name we could have "user_properies" which is more vocal imo.

(side-note, mentioning that this patch is done for npm wasn't needed at all.)

> (side-note, mentioning that this patch is done for npm wasn't needed at all.)

I think the intent was just to show that there is a real use-case for this feature.
@isaacs and we took it as such, no need to apologise or clarify.

Mmm I like this too.  Here's a half-baked solution for a white/blacklist approach:

``` erlang
-define(WHITELIST, [?NAME]).
-define(BLACKLIST, [?SALT,
            ?PASSWORD,
            ?PASSWORD_SCHEME,
            ?DERIVED_KEY,
            ?PBKDF2,
            ?ITERATIONS,
            <<"type">>,
            <<"roles">>,
            <<"password_sha">>]).

% ....

case couch_config:get("couchdb", "public_users", false) of
    "whitelist" ->
        Whitelist = couch_config:get("couchdb", "public_users_whitelist", ?WHITELIST)
        [ E || E <- Body, lists:member(E, Whitelist)];
    "blacklist" ->
        Blacklist = couch_config:get("couchdb", "public_users_blacklist", ?BLACKLIST)
        [ E || E <- Body, not(lists:member(Blacklist)];
    _ ->
    % couch_config will return nothing if public_users doesn't exist.
    % ...
```

we should keep it simple. There is no real need to support blacklisting and whitelisting. Also blacklisting may be hard to keep over the release since we don't promise that the doc properties will stay the same over the time.

@benoitc++.  I agree with simple.  Whitelisting adds an extra step in my process if I change the public fields in the npmjs.org user accounts, but it's not a hard step, or something I'll have to do often.  It's better to have the benefit of knowing that I'm not going to inadvertently leak anything that I didn't think of up front.

@dch as an admin you can't be sure that blacklisting will always work when you upgrade couchdb except if we make the promise to not add sensitive fields on update. Which we can't really do. Once we have the hot upgrade, it can be very problematic.
